questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. Over the past 8 months, his mother reports difficulty understanding the boy's speech. On occasion during this period, she has noticed that he does not respond when called by name and cannot follow 1-step instructions. He has a history of recurrent ear infections treated with antibiotics since birth. He is at the 60th percentile for length and 50th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. His speech is quiet and difficult to understand. Otoscopic examination shows retracted tympanic membranes bilaterally that are immobile on pneumatic otoscopy. Nasopharyngoscopy shows mild adenoid hypertrophy. Pure tone audiometry shows a conductive hearing loss of 26 dB on the right side and 28 dB on the left side. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decongestants are not recommended for the treatment of OME in children because studies have shown no effect on the time it takes OME to resolve, the prevention of complications such as recurrent otitis media or hearing loss, or the need for surgical intervention.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical antibiotics are used for the treatment of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM). While CSOM can also present with hearing loss, painless otorrhea is a key feature that is missing in this patient. Also, CSOM can be diagnosed by the presence of a perforated tympanic membrane on otoscopy. This patient presents with OME, for which antibiotic therapy is not recommended. While studies have shown modest, transient benefits in improving symptoms of OME, potential adverse reactions (e.g., diarrhea, vomiting, and allergic reactions) outweigh the benefits of topical antibiotic therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

While this boy has mild adenoid hypertrophy on physical examination, adenoidectomy is not recommended for the management of OME in children younger than 4 years of age unless there is an independent indication for adenoidectomy such as airway obstruction, chronic sinusitis, or chronic adenoiditis, which this patient does not have. Adenoidectomy has only been shown to improve the resolution of middle ear effusion in children ≥ 4 years and may be performed as first-line therapy in this age group.

D) CORRECT:

While OME resolves spontaneously in most cases and can be managed conservatively in older patients, this 3-year-old child has hearing loss at a point in time that is critical for speech and language development; it, therefore, requires prompt surgical intervention with the placement of a tympanostomy tube (also known as grommet tube, ear tube, or ventilation tube). The tube allows for the removal of fluid from the middle ear, decreases conductive hearing loss, and helps maintain an air-filled middle ear space.

Follow-ups should continue until the tympanic membrane is fully healed and normal eustachian tube function, as well as normal hearing, are achieved. Possible complications include otorrhea, occlusion of tubes, premature extrusion of tubes, persistent perforation, tympanosclerosis, and cholesteatoma.
Image Description:

The procedure can be performed under local or general anesthesia; general anesthesia is usually required for children. An operating microscope is preferred, although the procedure can be performed using a handheld operating otoscope.

1. A radial incision is made in the anterior-inferior quadrant of the pars tensa using a myringotomy blade.
2. Alligator forceps are used to insert the tympanostomy tube. Short-term tubes (I) are designed to self-extrude after approximately one year, whereas long-term tubes (II) have a longer flange that prevents extrusion.
3. A curved or angled pick can be used to facilitate correct placement.

E) INCORRECT:

Antihistamines are not recommended for the treatment of OME in children, since studies have shown no effect on the time it takes OME to resolve, the prevention of complications such as recurrent otitis media or hearing loss, or the need for surgical intervention.

F) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroid therapy is not generally recommended for the treatment of OME in children. The risk of adverse effects (e.g., growth retardation) is thought to outweigh the benefits of corticosteroid therapy. Studies have shown minimal efficacy in resolving OME and there is no evidence demonstrating improvements in hearing.
questions.hint: A history of recurrent ear infections, language developmental delay, and conductive hearing loss with retracted tympanic membranes that do not move briskly on pneumatic otoscopy is diagnostic of otitis media with effusion (OME).

questions.text:
An 18-year-old female college student presents with otalgia, muffled hearing, tinnitus, and aural fullness, all of which developed 2 weeks ago during an airline flight she took while experiencing concurrent nasal congestion and cough. The patient is otherwise healthy. Otoscopic examination reveals that the tympanic membrane is in the neutral position, appears thickened with an amber hue, and is immobile.
Which one of the following is the correct underlying diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute myringitis is characterized by an inflamed drum, decreased hearing, and, usually, scant ear drainage.

B) INCORRECT:

In acute otitis media, the tympanic membrane appears bulging and erythematous, often with a purulent effusion.

C) INCORRECT:

In chronic otitis media, the tympanic membrane appears scarred and retracted, and associated perforation or cholesteatoma may be present.

D) CORRECT:

During an upper respiratory tract infection, the mucosal linings of the eustachian tubes and nasal cavity swell, which may result in eustachian tube dysfunction and poor equilibrium between middle-ear pressure and atmospheric pressure. Barotrauma from air travel is more likely to occur in this setting and may cause middle-ear effusion, which can persist for up to a month. Symptoms of effusion include aural fullness, muffled hearing, tinnitus, and a sense of imbalance. Otalgia can accompany middle-ear effusion following barotrauma. Otoscopic examination will reveal a stiff tympanic membrane in a neutral or retracted position and an amber-colored middle-ear effusion.

Key learning point: In middle-ear effusions, the two most typical physical characteristics of the tympanic membrane are amber color and lack of mobility.

E) INCORRECT:

Hemotympanum may occur in the setting of barotrauma or basilar skull fracture but would appear as dark-red blood behind the tympanic membrane.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man reports that for the past week, he has had the sensation of his ears “popping” when he yawns or swallows, and his hearing in his right ear has been diminished. He reports no ear pain or drainage but did have nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, and mild cough one week ago that have since resolved.
He has a history of hypertension and mild intermittent epistaxis. He takes lisinopril and one baby aspirin daily. He does not smoke or drink alcohol.
On physical examination, he is afebrile. His right tympanic membrane is intact but appears dull and mildly retracted; it does not move with pneumatic otoscopy. Findings in his left ear are similar but less pronounced. Anterior rhinoscopy reveals normal turbinates and nasal mucosa; no blood, polyps, or lesions are evident. His throat appears normal, and his neck is normal on palpation.
Which one of the following strategies is most appropriate for acute management of this patient’s ear findings?

choices.text: Oral amoxicillin 500 mg three times daily for 10 days
Fluticasone nasal spray once daily until symptoms resolve
Pseudoephedrine 60 mg every 4 to 6 hours until symptoms resolve

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics such as amoxicillin do not play a role in treating OME.

B) INCORRECT:

Decongestant nasal sprays, glucocorticoid nasal sprays, oral decongestants, and oral antihistamines do not appear to shorten the recovery period. Oral glucocorticoids have not been clearly shown to be effective for this indication.

C) INCORRECT:

Myringotomy can alleviate the immediate ear blockage associated with OME and restore hearing. However, because the procedure increases the risk for middle-ear infection, it should be reserved for cases in which the fluid does not clear spontaneously or when planned air travel cannot be avoided.

D) CORRECT:

Otitis media with effusion (OME) is a common secondary complication of an acute upper respiratory infection. Nasal congestion from secretions or adenoid hypertrophy can lead to obstruction of the eustachian tube and resulting OME. OME is usually bilateral, although slight asymmetry in symptoms or examination findings, as seen in this case, is not unusual. Patients with bilateral OME should be observed. Unilateral OME should raise suspicion for a nasopharyngeal mass, such as nasopharyngeal cancer.

Decongestant nasal sprays, glucocorticoid nasal sprays, oral decongestants, and oral antihistamines do not appear to shorten the recovery period. Oral glucocorticoids have not been clearly shown to be effective for this indication.

Key learning point: Unilateral or bilateral serous otitis media is most appropriately managed with observation alone.

E) INCORRECT:

Decongestant nasal sprays, glucocorticoid nasal sprays, oral decongestants, and oral antihistamines do not appear to shorten the recovery period. Oral glucocorticoids have not been clearly shown to be effective for this indication.

questions.text:
An 18-month-old boy with a history of two ear infections during the past year presents with a 2-day history of temperature to 39.0°C, cough, and rhinorrhea. His parents report he has been sleeping through the night. He appears tired and has a wet-sounding cough and nasal congestion. Testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
He was treated with amoxicillin for his most recent ear infection 5 months ago and subsequently developed a rash. As a result, his parents were told that he should be considered allergic to amoxicillin. The boy has a vocabulary of about 20 words, according to his parents.
On examination, his temperature is 38.5°C. His tympanic membranes are intact and nonerythematous, with fluid present that obscures the light reflex.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Refer the child for insertion of tympanostomy tubes
Initiate an intranasal glucocorticoid and an antihistamine
Prescribe antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent recurrent acute otitis media
Recommend symptomatic management and reassess the child in 3 months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tympanostomy tubes would be appropriate in a child with any of the following:

• Recurrent acute otitis media (defined as three episodes in 6 months or four episodes in one year) with evidence of middle-ear effusion at the time of evaluation
• Middle-ear effusion lasting >3 months
• Middle-ear effusion with speech delay, hearing difficulties, or both

B) INCORRECT:

The combination of an intranasal glucocorticoid and an antihistamine is effective for a child with allergic rhinitis but is not recommended for a middle-ear effusion. Furthermore, the safety of intranasal glucocorticoids for children under 3 years of age is not well established. Most antihistamines are safe for children older than 6 months.

C) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic therapy is not needed for middle-ear effusion in the absence of acute otitis media. If antibiotic therapy were needed, the typical antibiotic recommendation for a child with an amoxicillin allergy would be a third-generation oral cephalosporin. Inner-ear pathogens are now highly resistant to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

D) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic prophylaxis is not recommended for children with long-term middle-ear effusion; the benefit is not worth the harm of antibiotic side effects, allergic reactions, and bacterial resistance.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's symptoms suggest an upper respiratory infection with accompanying middle-ear effusion. He has no reported signs of acute otitis media, such as otalgia, tympanic membrane bulging, tympanic membrane erythema, or otorrhea. The effusion could be resolving from a previous ear infection or may be the start of a new ear infection. The most appropriate next step is to follow up in 3 months to monitor for resolving effusion. If effusion is present, hearing assessment is indicated.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step for a normally developing toddler with a history of recent otitis media who presents with fever, upper respiratory infection, and a middle-ear effusion is follow-up in 3 months for reassessment of the middle-ear effusion.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy presents with a one-week history of intermittent pain in his left ear. Four weeks ago, he was diagnosed with acute otitis media in his left ear. His fever and pain resolved with a 10-day course of amoxicillin.
His parents report that during the past week, he has been occasionally pulling at his left ear again but that he has remained afebrile. The parents have not noted any issues with his hearing or speech.
On examination, he has a heart rate of 100 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 80/60 mm Hg, and a temperature of 37.2°C. His right tympanic membrane appears normal, but the left tympanic membrane is amber in color and retracted with an air-fluid level. Pneumatic otoscopy shows diminished mobility of the left tympanic membrane compared with the right.
Which one of the following initial strategies is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Otitis media with effusion is caused by the accumulation of noninfected fluid in the middle ear. It can result from eustachian tube dysfunction, an upper respiratory infection, or acute otitis media; 75% to 90% of cases resolve spontaneously within 3 months. Thus, watchful waiting for up to 3 months is the recommended management when there are no concerns for speech or hearing difficulties.

Key learning point: The most appropriate care for a toddler who has otitis media with effusion but no hearing or speech problems is watchful waiting.

B) INCORRECT:

Audiologic evaluation may be recommended when otitis media with effusion lasts longer than 3 months. It should also be considered earlier when there are concerns that a child has hearing difficulties or speech delay.

C) INCORRECT:

Tympanostomy tube placement by an otolaryngologist would be considered when an otitis media with effusion lasts >3 months. It would also be considered when a child has recurrent episodes or is at risk of developing hearing impairment.

D) INCORRECT:

Given that the fluid in the middle ear in otitis media with effusion is not typically infected, antibiotics are not recommended. Thus, a repeat course of amoxicillin is not necessary.

E) INCORRECT:

Analgesics can be used to treat the pain associated with otitis media with effusion, but systemic glucocorticoids, such as prednisolone, have not been shown to be effective and are therefore not recommended for routine treatment.

questions.text:
An 18-month-old boy presents for a well-child check. He is at the 55th percentile for weight and length and is tracking well. On developmental assessment, he refers to his parents by name and then points, but he is not naming any other objects or putting two-word sentences together.
He was treated with gentamicin for a bacterial meningitis infection at 2 months of age. A grandparent had a diagnosis of congenital deafness, and a cousin has neurofibromatosis of unknown type.
Audiometry is performed (figure); normal thresholds are ≤20 dB at each frequency. Tympanograms are flat bilaterally, with low ear-canal volume.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Congenital deafness is usually familial and nearly always sensorineural; connexin 26 mutations are the most common cause.

B) INCORRECT:

Aminoglycosides, such as gentamicin, are toxic to cochlear hair cells and can lead to sensorineural hearing loss.

C) INCORRECT:

Bacterial meningitis is a common cause of acquired sensorineural hearing loss.

D) INCORRECT:

Vestibular schwannoma can occur in patients with neurofibromatosis type 2 and would lead to sensorineural hearing loss.

E) CORRECT:

A typical 18-month-old child should have a vocabulary of 15 to 20 words, so a child who says only “mama” and “dada” can be considered to have a language delay. Deficits in hearing are a common cause of language delay.

When sound conducted through air is abnormal but sound conducted through bone is normal, the diagnosis is conductive hearing loss. Bilateral otitis media with effusion leads to conductive hearing loss by preventing the tympanic membrane from vibrating appropriately and transmitting sound through the ossicles to the cochlea via the oval window.

Key learning point: A child whose hearing is poor when noise is transmitted via air conduction but better when transmitted via bone conduction has conductive hearing loss.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents to the ED with a minor arm laceration after a playground injury. While obtaining the history, you notice the child frequently looks to his parents to answer questions and does not respond until questions are repeated loudly. His parents report he has been turning up the television volume at home for the last month but has had no recent fever, ear pain, or illness. Vital signs are normal. Otoscopic exam is shown. The arm laceration has been cleaned and closed. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for his ear symptoms in the ED?

choices.text: Prescribe oral prednisone and nasal decongestants
Arrange ENT referral for tympanostomy tube placement
Schedule follow-up with primary care in 3 months to reassess
Prescribe amoxicillin and schedule follow-up in 1 week
Discharge with no follow-up and reassurance the effusion will self-resolve

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Steroids, antihistamines, and decongestants are not routinely indicated for otitis media with effusion and have not been shown to be effective in managing this condition.

B) INCORRECT:

ENT referral is indicated for otitis media with effusion if there is tympanic membrane damage or after documented hearing loss following 3 months of persistent effusion. This patient does not meet those criteria.

C) CORRECT:

Correct– this represents standard watchful waiting for otitis media with effusion (OME). Primary care follow-up allows for reassessment; if OME persists at 3 months, formal audiometry should be performed, and if hearing loss is documented, ENT referral is indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics are not indicated for otitis media with effusion because there are no signs of acute infection. The absence of fever, pain, and bulging tympanic membrane indicates otitis media with effusion rather than acute otitis media.

E) INCORRECT:

Although effusions often resolve spontaneously, monitoring is essential. Without follow-up, persistent effusion could lead to academic and social difficulties from prolonged hearing loss
